quizzes.title: History Quiz: History and Murders
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, actor, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Certainly one of the most dreadful serial killers in US history. Even though he performed as a clown at neghborhood childrens parties, he killed 33 teenagers.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Wayne Gacy

questions.question: Henry Lee Lucas confessed to more than 500 murders. How many murders was he actually convicted of?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 11

questions.question: He delivered the famous I have a dream speech.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Martin Luther King Jr.

questions.question: He disliked Jews and accused them of causing all disasters in German history.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hitler

questions.question: This serial killer was known as The Candy Man. His partner,  Wayne Henley, eventually shot him.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dean Corll

questions.question: He was the only actor to become US President.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ronald Reagan

questions.question: He was the first democratically-elected President of South Africa.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nelson Mandela

questions.question: He brought the cause of Indias independence to world attention.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mohandas Gandhi

questions.question: Which British Prime Minister is considered to have saved his country during WW2?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Winston Churchill

questions.question: There are many theories about the identity of this mysterious British serial killer. He marks the dawn of the modern age of serial murders. Although the number of his victims is not high, compared to others on our list (5), he is probably the worlds most famous serial murderer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jack The Ripper

questions.question: He was the only Pope of non-Italian origin since the Dutch-German Pope Adrian VI.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pope John Paul II

questions.question: This serial killer terrorized Washington, Oregon, Colorado, Utah, and Florida. His death sentence was executed in Florida on 24 January 1989.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ted Bundy

questions.question: This mans rampage lasted from 1979 to 1981. He roamed Atlanta and Georgia, taking the lives of 27 innocent boys. At first the police thought he was a white supremacist, because he targeted black boys, but it turned out he was black himself.  He was caught on 22 May 1981.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wayne Williams

questions.question: Bruno Ludke was born in 1909. When he was young, he tortured animals for fun. He strangled or stabbed to death 85 women.  Where was he from?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Germany

questions.question: She was the only woman to become Prime Minister of Great Britain.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Margaret Thatcher

quizzes.title: Sports Quiz: George and Works
quizzes.description: Test your sports knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Sports, john, novelists. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This George lived for only 40 years - from 1593 until 1633. Nevertheless, he became a great poet. However, none of his works was published while he was alive.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Herbert

questions.question: This John was a member of one of the most popular bands from the 60s.  Earlier, he has formed his own band called The Quarrymen.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Lennon

questions.question: His most famous works were Childe Harolds Pilgrimage and Don Juan. His fame rests not only on his romantic poems; he was known for his lifestyle, which included extravagant living, debts, separation, claims of incest, etc.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Gordon Byron

questions.question: Before becoming an important political figure, this George was a businessman, involved with the oil industry and then with professional sports.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George W Bush

questions.question: This George is one of the greatest English novelists. The term Big Brother comes from his book 1984.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Orwell

questions.question: This George was the first president of the USA. Although the American capital city was named after him, he never lived there.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Washington

questions.question: This George was actually a woman and her real name was Mary Ann Evans. She used a male pen name because she wanted the publishers to take her works seriously.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Eliot

questions.question: He established the first fascist party.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Benito Mussolini

questions.question: This John was a writer. He received the Nobel price for literature in 1962 for his realistic and imaginative writing, combining as it does sympathetic humour and keen social perception.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Steinbeck

questions.question: This George was also a woman. Her real name was Amandine-Aurore-Lucile Dupin. She was a feminist before the invention of the word. She had a romantic relationship with Chopin.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Sand

questions.question: In 1997 this George was voted Sexiest Man Alive by People magazine. His first TV role was in the TV series E/R.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Clooney

questions.question: This George is the director of one of the most famous movie sagas. However the script for this saga was initially turned down by every major Hollywood studio because no one would want to see it.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Lucas

questions.question: This George received the Nobel Prize in literature in 1925 but he didnt take the prize money. Instead, he gave the money for funding the translation of Swedish literature into English.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Bernard Shaw

questions.question: The name he is known as means Awakened One, Enlightened One.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Buddha

questions.question: This famous English poet is the author of Paradise Lost. The long hours of writing under the light of a candle cost him his eyesight. He then started using a scribe.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Milton

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: John and Explorer
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, john, actor. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This John majored in philology, which triggered his interest in linguistics. This enabled him to invent 15 artificial languages. Two of them are most popular: Quenya and Sindarin, the two Elvish languages in The Lord of the Rings.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Tolkien

questions.question: This John was one of the greatest English poets in the 17th century. He belonged to the group of the so-called metaphysical poets. It was his meditations that gave Hemingway the idea about the title of For Whom the Bell Tolls.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Donne

questions.question: This great explorer is famous for his fulfilment of the first all water trade route between India and Europe .
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vasco da Gama

questions.question: This seafarer John was captured by the Indians around 1600. He reported in his account that the Indian chief wanted to club him to death. He was saved by the 11-12 year old daughter of the chief, who stood between her father and the Englishman.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Smith

questions.question: The real name of this John was Marion Robert Morrison. When his brother was born, the name Robert was given to him and the former became Marion Michael Morrison. Then he got the nickname Duke. Most sources state that his first movie was Words and Music (1929).
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Wayne

questions.question: This great Spanish explorer conquered what is now central and southern Mexico.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hernando Cortes

questions.question: This great explorer found a new continent thinking he had found a new way to India.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Christopher Columbus

questions.question: Besides being an actor, this Pulp Fiction John is a certified pilot and owns a couple of planes.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Travolta

questions.question: By his circumnavigation around the world, which took three years, from 1577 to 1580, this explorer gave a more accurate picture of the true geography of the world.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sir Francis Drake

questions.question: This man is also known as Karol Wojtyla and Juan Pablo II. His reign as a Pope was the third-longest in the history of the Papacy. He named himself after his predecessor, who died suddenly after only 33 days of service to God.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Paul II

questions.question: Along with his brother, this famous explorer reached Kaifeng, the capital of Kublai Khans Mongol Empire in 1265.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marco Polo

questions.question: This mans voyages were the base for Frances claim to Canada. His initial intention was to search for the Northwest Passage to the Orient.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jacques Cartier

questions.question: This great explorer spent years searching for a seaway to China in order to trade Spains New World gold, thus contributing with information about America before its Indian cities were destroyed by foreign diseases.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hernando de Soto

questions.question: This John is the one who said Ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Kennedy

questions.question: He is famous for sailing around the world twice. He became the first European to visit the coasts of Hawaii and Australia. Due to his voyages  some colonies were established throughout the Pacific region by several European nations.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Cook

quizzes.title: Nature Quiz: Man and Job
quizzes.description: Test your nature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Nature, people, country. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who made this popular statement in July 1969: Thats one small step for (a) man, one giant leap for mankind.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Neil Armstrong

questions.question: As a Banana Gasser, what gas would you use to catalyze the ripening of bananas?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ethylene

questions.question: Ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country. These words were delivered by which US President?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John F. Kennedy

questions.question: These guys provide the primary ingredient for life-saving serums to people who have been bitten by poisonous snakes.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Snake Milkers

questions.question: Have you ever noticed that not all onions are created equal? Some are bigger, some smaller, some differ in color and this person has to sort them.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Onion Graders

questions.question: What does a Golf Ball Marshal do?

options.text: They search for lost golf balls

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They search for lost golf balls

questions.question: Which scientist is credited with the following quote: I never think of the future - it comes soon enough.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Albert Einstein

questions.question: Are your taste buds working over time?  If so, this job might be perfect for you. John Harrison is doing this job for the Dreyers.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ice Cream Taster

questions.question: Which famous boxer said that he would float like a butterfly and sting like a bee.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Muhammad Ali

questions.question: What does a Wrinkle Chaser do?

options.text: Studies the wrinkles on someones face

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Irons wrinkles from shoes

questions.question: Famous for his sea explorations, this man helped develop the first self-contained underwater breathing apparatus (SCUBA).
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jacques Cousteau

questions.question: People who do this job are responsible for making 3-D films look so real.  They create the hairstyles of the animated characters.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hair Simulation Supervisors

questions.question: Which US President said: I am not a crook.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Richard Nixon

questions.question: He was the first man to explore Antarctica by land. He led two expeditions with the intention to find out more about the animals, weather and geology of the Antarctic.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Captain Scott

questions.question: A Vermiculturist uses this animal to produce compost?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Worms

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Words and Rulers
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, rappers, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What famous person delivered these words: I have nothing new to teach the world. Truth and non-violence are as old as the hills.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mahatma Gandhi

questions.question: The lefty, Henry Ford, founded the Ford Motor Company. Finish this quote and find out how he defined quality.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: ...no one is looking.

questions.question: During her trial, Joan of Arc was accused of being left-handed.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which US President said the following words: Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation, conceived in Liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Abraham Lincoln

questions.question: Which of these rulers / politicians was not left-handed?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They were all left-handed

questions.question: One of the following terrorist leaders can be described as a tall and thin man with an olive complexion and a cane, who is left-handed and always wears a plain white turban.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Osama bin Laden

questions.question: These words belong to which famous writer: Always do right. This will gratify some people and astonish the rest.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mark Twain

questions.question: Ronald Reagan was a left-handed President.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which fashion designer made this statement: Fashion passes, style remains.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Coco Chanel

questions.question: The Roman emperor, Tiberius, was a left-handed ruler, who belonged to what dynasty?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Julio-Claudian dynasty

questions.question: Who made a speech, known by the popular name I Have a Dream?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Martin Luther King Jr

questions.question: Which famous politician said: We must all hang together, or, most assuredly, we shall all hang separately.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Benjamin Franklin

questions.question: Who is credited with delivering the following words: 100% of the shots you dont take dont go in.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wayne Gretzky

questions.question: Raphael was a left-handed painter and architect of the Florentine school in the Italian High Renaissance. One of these works does not belong to him.

options.text: Woman with a veil (La Donna Velata)

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Night Watch

questions.question: Both rappers, 50 Cent and Eminem, are left-handed.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.title: Literature Quiz: Father and Poet
quizzes.description: Test your literature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Literature, actor, opportunity. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Jay Leno is a left-handed American comedian, who suffers from what disease?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dyslexia

questions.question: O. Henry was working as a bank teller when he was sent to jail for embezzlement.  He spent 3 years in jail where he started writing his short stories.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William Sydney Porter

questions.question: This is the last movie in which the lefty, Charlie Chaplin appeared.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A Countess from Hong Kong

questions.question: Nelson Rockefeller, the left-handed 41st Vice President of the United States of America, was a governor of this state before becoming Vice President.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New York

questions.question: After achieving success with his horror stories, this writer called himself Richard Bachman because he wanted to see if his novels would sell without his already famous name on them.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Stephen King

questions.question: Paul Eluard was a major exponent of surrealism.  Many of his poems reflect the hardship after his separation with his first wife Gala, who left him for Salvador Dali.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Eugène Grindel

questions.question: Lewis Carroll conceived Alices Adventures in Wonderland as nursery tales for the daughter of a friend.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Charles Lutwidge Dodgson

questions.question: The left-handed actor, Jim Carrey, played what character in the 2004 Hollywood production, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joel

questions.question: Both in the year when Mark Twain was born and the year when he died, the Halleys Comet passed by Earth.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Samuel Langhorne Clemens

questions.question: Moliere became famous as the father of French high comedy. He coined the phrase castigat ridendo mores (to criticise customs through humour) which is sometimes mistaken for a genuine Latin proverb.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jean Baptiste Poquelin

questions.question: Stendhal hated his father so he took the first opportunity to leave for Paris, where he became a lieutenant in Napoleon’s army.  He began his literary career after the fall of Napoleon in 1814.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marie Henri Beyle

questions.question: Saki was a master of short stories.  It is said that his pen name could be a reference to a monkey with the same name.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hector Hugh Munro

questions.question: Besides a poet, Pablo Neruda was also a diplomat and a Communist leader.  He changed his original name because he didnt want his father to find out he was a poet.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ricardo Eliecer Neftalí Reyes Basoalto

questions.question: The left-handed Hollywood actor, Morgan Freeman, was born in which city?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Memphis

questions.question: Anatole France was probably the most famous French man of letters of his time.  In 1921 he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jacques Anatole Thibault
